answers.answer: Hi,I am not an expert, but I believe both are related to Diabetic Neuropathy. He should immediately check up with a Doctor and should not hide any symptoms from the doctor.Solace

LadyQ, I certainly am no expert in the field either, but I am a Type 2 diabetic who was diagnosed about 4 years ago.  Im not to sure how the tingly feeling would fit in with diabetes, unless youre thinking diabetic neropathy.  Its my understanding that neuropathy normally strikes in the feet/toes first.  (Furthest from the heart, less circulation)The urination thing is something I went through until I got my blood sugar under control.  I never wet the bed, but was up 2-3 times a night to go to the bathroom.I'd suggest going to your general/family practitioner and bring the symptoms up.  Have your husband go in on a fast for about 12 hours and have his blood sugar checked right there.  (They poke a finger, take a drop of blood and put it on a tester)  The results are within seconds, but your doctor would probably suggest a full blood lab.Hope that helps.

Thanks for the replies.  I think right now we are going to chalk the accident up to a really deep sleep plus a really vivid dream.  He had not slept good the few nights before but apparently slept too well that night of the bed accident.  He was dreaming he was going to the restroom and woke up and had already done it.  But he will still go to the doc for his shoulder pain + tingling sensation.  Although the tinglies never returned.  When he's there he will have his routine bloodwork done since he didn't return for his follow-up visit 2 years ago.  If the bed accidents happen again he has agreed to discuss it with his doc.  But so far so good. :)Thanks!

Normal fasting blood sugar should be 100 or below. His Dr can easily check it in his office. Make sure your husband has had nothing but water 12 hours before the test. The arm tingling sounds like it's possibly heart related. I'm not trying to scare you because it could very well be something else. Does he get indigestion or any other symptoms? I know it might be impossible to get your husband to agree to a prostate exam but he really should have one done because it might have something to do with the wetting problem.  Remar

question: My husband will be 38 years old this week.  He doesn't have any major health problems, doesn't smoke, doesn't drink, etc.  He is a normal weight (190 at 6'1").  But his eating habits are awful and he doesn't exercise regularly, although he is active (NOT a couch potato type).  He has a family Hx of diabetes and heart problems. His LDL and sugar levels were borderline last time he went for a checkup (2 yrs ago).  Dr told him to eat a lowfat diet and return in 2 months, neither of which happened.Here are his two symptoms that happened in 24 hours that have me concerned and I wonder if they are something to go to the doctor about and if they are possibly related.  He is not concerned at all, but you know how men are.First on the way home from church yesterday morning he said that his left arm went tingly/numb like it had fallen asleep, but he was just sitting there (not propped on anything).  It only last a moment, but then a little while later it got tingly again for a few seconds and then was okay again.  He has had some problems with pain in his left shoulder over the past few months that we think is associated to a neck injury he had about 15 years ago (he was thrown off a horse).  He received chiropractic therapy for his neck.  But the past several years his left shoulder/arm gives him trouble - and he thinks it's related to his neck problem.  Yesterday when he had the tinglies he told me maybe it was time to see a doctor.The tinglies were yesterday before lunch.  Then this morning at 5 a.m. I heard him get up to go to the bathroom, but heard him making a racket in there and asked him what he was doing.  Then it turned out he had wet the bed :(  We've been married 10 years and to my knowledge that has never happened.  He does get up just about every night to use the restroom in the middle of the night, and he told me a time or two he had a few 'close calls' where he had a few trickles before he made it to the toilet.  But this is the first time he lost it all in the bed.  He said he was dreaming he was going to the restroom and when he woke up he had already done it in the bed.Is this just random that both these things happened in a 24 hour period?  I know that for a man to wet the bed is not uncommon and may not be a sign of anything major. He told me he will NOT discuss this with his doctor (his doc goes to church with us, so maybe that's why, but he said he still would not talk to a dr about it).My concern is that the tinglies in his left arm and the incontinence could be a sign of diabetes.  He has been consuming a lot of liquids lately because we live in the south where the heat indexes are in the 100s and he works in a manufacturing plant where it gets kinda hot in there. I wouldn't be so worried about the diabetes with these 2 symptoms alone, but he drinks at least 3 canned sodas a day, craves sweets like you wouldn't believe, and rarely eats veggies (he's a meat/bread/potatoes man - will eat some veggies when I cook them but very little).Also - if this helps at all....he was craving 'breakfast for supper' last night.  So we made bacon, eggs and pancakes.  He eat 2 pancakes, 1 ½ scrambled eggs (cooked in the bacon grease), and probably 6-8 slices of low-sodium bacon.  I know! The man likes bacon!  I told him it was bad but he doesn't care.  He drank 2 canned sodas with it also.  And this was at about 8:00 p.m. when he ate it.  We went to bed about 11 p.m.  Maybe that had something to do with his fluid retention/loss of bladder control?Anyway - just wanted to post my concerns to see what feedback I would get.  Thanks!
title: 2 strange symptoms? Related or not?
